text: if you believe the hype in five years
time you'll probably be watching this on
a 3d printed telly sitting on your 3d
printed sofa drinking a 3d printed cup
of tea I'll probably be 3d printed - but
it's undeniable that in the last few
years 3d printing has exploded and it's
not just architects designers and other
creative salts that are getting their
cravats in a twist about the technology
that some people even have in their
homes for the uninitiated 3d printing is
the process of creating a
three-dimensional solid object from a
digital model normally if you wanted to
make something out of stone for example
you'd start with a big block and hack
away at it 3d printing starts with
nothing and adds material layer by layer
to create the exact shape you want using
this process you can create really
anything for bits of space rockets -
well Christmas ornaments we've got three
3d printers to put to the test to do
exactly that the laser-cut Ultimaker
original instantly betrays its maker
community roots its design may not be to
everyone's tastes but it does have a
certain backroom chic to it
it uses a process called fused filament
fabrication which means it very
accurately lays down melted plastic
layer by layer until the almost always
obscure object of your desire appears
before your eyes coming in at just under
a thousand pounds it's the cheapest of
the printers we're looking at the
Ultimaker is already calibrated before
it leaves the factory but during our 3d
print fans may want to tinker themselves
3d printers are operating over tiny tiny
distances so even tenth of a millimeter
in accuracy could turn your carefully
planned print into a plasticy mess once
it was set up we printed our festive
test a snowman about 30 minutes later he
emerged freshly printed and ready to
spread festive cheer the space-age form
1 is the slickest looking about test
printers a huge success on Kickstarter
technically it works slightly
differently to the other printers rather
than printing in plastic this machine
uses lasers the form one shoots a laser
similar to the one you find in a blu-ray
player at a vat of photo polymer resin
wherever the laser hits it solidifies
into hardened plastic do this a few
thousand times you've got yourself
another Christmas tree ornament
it doesn't require any calibration once
you've plugged it in and downloaded the
software onto your computer you're ready
to print the form wands bundled software
preform was the best that we tried
printing our snowman
this time transparent took much longer
though over two hours a point five
millimeter of resolution once it's done
there's a fairly long post-processing
stage evolving rubber gloves and rubbing
alcohol while the whole process is a lot
slower and our tests it produced
smoother looking models with much finer
looking details coming in at around
2,000 pounds this is the most expensive
printer on test
like the Ultimaker the awkwardly named
be the first is another fused filament
fabricator that means it basically melts
plastic not a single laser beam in sight
the software claims full cross-platform
support but we found that it was a bit
clunky and shortened options once
calibrated though the be the first was a
nice device to use producing a perfectly
formed minute of snowman in point one
millimeter resolution this is only a
small selection of 3d printers that are
on the market at the moment
these are definitely enthusiast machines
and you do need to be slightly technical
to use them but I suspect not too
distant future devices like these will
become much more commonplace
